comment_body.0:
Thanks in advance for the help y'all. Looking for my first car without the parent's help. 18 months removed from college, recession/depression-proof job (thank god and Semper Fi), and looking for something fun to drive for the next 5-7 years before my eventual wife makes me give it up in the name of practicality.

Location: "Fuckin' Texas"'

Price range: $20,000 - $32,000

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Sports car (slightly prefer Sedan vs. Coupe)

Must haves: Fun to drive, >20 mpg highway, (apple carplay, adaptive cruise control, moonroof huge plus but not dealbreakers)

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Can't drive stick but willing to learn (before I buy)

Intended use: Daily Driver

Vehicles you've already considered:

  • 2018-2020 Dodge Charger or Challenger GT or RT
  • 2017-2020 Ford Mustang GT
  • 2016-2018 Subaru WRX
  • 2019 Genesis G70 (3.3 likely out of price range though)
  • 2017-2019 VW Golf GTI

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: Trying to buy lightly used so no, but would be a plus

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: would like to learn, most advanced I ever see myself going is probably coil-overs or intake/exhaust
comment_body.3:
Hi all. Looking for a good daily that I can take for a road trip to good skiing and backpacking the moment the opportunity comes up. I have little to interest in extraneous tech in a car outside of seat heaters, and prefer older, well-vetted hardware over the latest in infotainment and HUD, though I would really like some sort of adaptive cruise control and anti-collision braking. I'm at the point in my life where I can afford to spend some money on not regularly wrenching or being in a shop, and I'd like to take advantage of it!

Location: SW USA

Price range: ~$30,000

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Either. If used, prefer <~60k mi.

Type of vehicle: Open to options. Prefer no crossover, but something with some ground clearance and room in the back for gear is preferable.

Must haves: 4WD/AWD, Hatch, >20MPG, good track record of reliability

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): No preference

Intended use: Daily driver first, ski bum and backpacking rig second.

Vehicles you've already considered: Subaru Outback/Crosstrek, Tacoma, 4runner

Is this your 1st vehicle: Definitely not

Do you need a Warranty: Would be nice, but not necessary.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: some
comment_body.4:
I’m downsizing; my wife and I each have a commuter, and we have an additional Honda Odyssey. Two kids in car seats. We’ll be dropping one car. I’m trying to decide which to keep: a 2015 Prius or a 2014 Odyssey, both with similar mileage.

Making the Odyssey a commuter gives us more flexibility and space, but gas mileage is poor and it’s hard to park in the tightly spaced garage at work.

Keeping the Prius has huge advantages for reliability and gas mileage, but at the expense of utility.

Some outside perspective would be awesome.
comment_body.5:
Location: Southeast United States

Price Range: 20,000 - 28,000USD

Buy

New (or CPO less than 3 years old)

Type: Sedan, Wagon, Crossover

Must have: fuel efficient (lots of stop and go on the way to work), cargo space

Transmission: any

Intended Use: daily driver, weekend hiking trips

Cars I've considered:. 2018-2020 Hyundai Ioniq SEL, 2019-2020 Honda Insight EX, 2019 Buick Regal TourX (if the MPGs were better this would be my choice), 2020 Toyota Corolla hybrid, 2019-2020 Kia Niro.

Second car purchase as a family

Warranty: if possible! Last car had transmission issue that was fixed under warranty. Thank God

I can change a tire, top off fluids and change my oil. Past that it's off to a mechanic.

I really want a wagon, but options in the states are not the best unless you have loads of $$$ to drop on one of the new Volvo ones. Due to transmission issues with my VW Jetta I'm probably going to avoid VW in the future. The European spec'd Toyota Corolla Touring Sports Hybrid would be the perfect car for me, but it's probably never coming to the US because SUVs. Leaning towards the Ioniq for the hatchback and MPGs but open to suggestions!
comment_body.6:
Location: (Specify your country or region): USA (Live in CA, will register in WI)

Price range: (Minimum-Maximum in your local currency): $75k +/-

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Either

Type of vehicle: Coupe - "Fun car"

Must haves: Make the right noise(s), handle well, quick (<4.0 sec 0-60), fit me comfortably in the driver's seat (6'1" @ 230 lbs), NO carbon ceramics for brakes

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Either, wife prefers auto though

Intended use: Fun car + 25 miles round trip drive to work 2/3 days a week

Vehicles you've already considered: Audi R8 (Gen 1 V10 preferred), 2020 Corvette, MB AMG GT, Jaguar F-Type SVR (or R), Porsche 911, Gallardo

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: It would be nice, but not necessary

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No, but my neighbor is quite a skilled mechanic

Additional Notes: I've been driving a Chevy Volt for the last 9 years; I'm dead inside from it. Time for something that is fast, loud, and gives me butterflies in my stomach when I see it in the garage.

Additional Notes: Currently have a 987.1 Cayman S that I use for daily, canyon drives, and would like to eventually track. This has been a great daily for me, but with the addition of a dog and kids in the near future, would need more space for transport as I've had to borrow cars to bring the dog anywhere. Was looking at the hot hatches above, and was really starting to like the Veloster N, but wanted to get everyones opinion regarding other options out there, to make sure I'm not missing on anything. Have also been looking at M3 sedans.

comment_body.10:
Filling this one out for my dad.

Location: California, USA

Price range: $5000

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: wagon, crossover, sedan

Must haves: MPG better than 15 mpg, real rear doors, usable cargo space

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): auto

Intended use: Daily driver capable of hauling around 2 kids under 10 and their needed items

Vehicles you've already considered: M-B E320 Estate, Volvo V70, Subaru Legacy/Outback wagons

Is this your 1st vehicle: no

Do you need a Warranty: no

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: some (dad is retired mechanic)

Additional Notes: Dad had a '06 Scion XB that was recently totaled in a rear end hit-n-run. It was the perfect car for his needs (Toyota reliability, 4 doors, OK sized rear storage area, good gas mileage.) Since then he's been driving around in his '06 Tundra Access Cab and he's realized it's not great for hauling around 2 grand kids due to the height of the vehicle and the door arrangement (need to open front doors before you can open the rear doors, which hinge from the back).

He's been shopping for post-2000 wagons including E320 estates (W210), V70s, and Subaru Legacies/Outbacks.

Is there anything else he should take a look at?

comment_body.18:
Is getting an older, well maintained, all original, garage kept, "classic," car as a daily driver a bad idea?

My daily was totaled in an accident a couple of years ago. I then started driving my old Tacoma until I get a new car. I've saved enough money for a decent used car.

Two weeks ago, I came across a 1989 Civic imported from Japan. The person who's selling it claims to have had it since the early 2000s. He's kept it in his garage the whole time with just an occasional drive. The shape is incredible, both interior and exterior, everything is original, only 44k miles, paperwork for all the maintenance he's done on it.

Would I be an idiot for buying this to make it my daily, because I can get another newer car for the same price with modern features and today's safety standards?

The main reasons I want to get this is nostalgia (my very first car was a 1990 Civic hatch) and I really like the look of 80s and 90s Hondas.

I tried submitting this as it's own thread but it keeps getting deleted.

Any ideas?
comment_body.30: Sup is there a car similar to the Honda Accord (size and reliability) except it's more fun to drive?
comment_body.31:
Location: Ohio, USA.

Price range: Less than 20k USD

Lease or Buy: Buy

New or used: Used

Type of vehicle: Either convertible, or offroad-capable

Must haves: Fun.

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual

Intended use: Daily driver, rock climbing & camping trips, but not necessarily my only car. No track or rally usage.

Vehicles you've already considered: Mazda Miata, Jeep Wrangler, VW Alltrack, Ford Mustang

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: (fluids, alternator, battery, brake pads etc) Yes

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: (engine and transmission, timing belt/chains, body work, suspension etc ) No

Additional Notes: Currently have a 2009 Ford Fusion that is so disappointing I wish it would grenade already. Thankfully, it's helped me get through college and now I graduate this Spring -- thankfully with a nice job lined up that isn't being impacted by the ongoing crisis. As a rock climber, I want something that can carry a good amount of gear (trunk space), is comfortable for a four hour drive, has a manual transmission, is fun, and can go over some gravel in the rain in a pinch. I want a convertible because that's just fun, particularly since everywhere I go climbing has excellent roads and beautiful summers. However, convertibles and storage space kinda don't go together. I would love the Wrangler, but I'm just concerned about FCA reliability and the higher prices.

My options: get a cheap Miata for shits and giggles, and keep my current beater. It's paid off and never breaks. Or, get a Mustang because it's still a convertible, while being more comfortable than the Miata. Or, get a Wrangler, to enjoy convertible and capability albeit with a much higher price tag. Probably would dump the Fusion in that case. Or, get the VW Alltrack because station wagons are cool in their own way, plus has incredible storage space and still some AWD capability, again dumping the Fusion. I know this is a really strange cross-shop, but I've got plenty of time and money since dealers are struggling so much.

Oh, and I forgot to mention: I don't drive to work. I take the bus. Commuting is not an issue with any vehicle.

Vehicles Considered Honda Fit(can get a newer one and is a pretty good car but it's a bit boring), Mazda MX-5(can't find newer ones in the budget), Nissan 350z(high insurance for teen drivers?)

First Car Yes

Warranty idk?

Minor Work I don't know anything about working on cars but I'm interested to learn. Willing to do risk free work. Parents can't help with it.

Major Work Nope.

Additional Notes I'm 16 and looking for a first car, parents are not car people (dad drives a Tesla and mom drives a Sienna). I know a decent amount about cars but not about working on them or internals(I can jump start a car but nothing more which is honestly better than most of my peers). Definitely interested in doing some work and learning but I don't want to do anything that has high risk involved or could lead to expensive repairs. If I can't find anything else I'll probably end up in a Honda Fit but I want my first car to be fun or something cool.

Edit: attempted to fix formatting on mobile and added WRX to the vehicles considered.

Edit 2: I don't need the car immediately, I need it to drive to school, competitions, and other places to hang out with friends on weekends(usual HS stuff) but I have transportation to school for this school year and I can get rides with people for other things so I plan on buying before school starts (start actively taking test drives and physically looking at cars in June).

has to be a simple TDI engine which are reliable AF, do not consider PD engines like VAG's 1,9 74kW because they are expensive to repair in case of clog up, or whatever there happens in case of poorer diesel fuel, currently have golf mk2 1,6D 40kW and would like to get something comparable in terms of maintenance cost and fuel economy, but a bit more comfortable, quieter, rust on the body is not acceptable, because any damaged paint spot would just ruin entire looks in just 1 winter, when roads are covered in salt, so i need a car with strong body, perfectly - zinc covered( idk how to translate that properly).

comment_body.44:
• Location: New York metro area, potentially willing to fly anywhere in the US to buy a car.

  • Price range: 10-20k, no more

  • Lease or Buy: Buy

  • New or used: Used

  • Type of vehicle: Ideally a sports car. No bigger than a midsize sedan.

  • Must haves: All the driving fun I can afford. Space for someone 6’. Not too loud on the highway. Apple CarPlay, or a space to put a head unit that has it, is key. Less than 70k miles. More than 20 mpg city. Blind spot monitoring, if it’s hard to see out of. Nice to haves are navigation, leather seats, LED lights. It’d be really nice to have a limited slip differential.

  • **Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Manual.

  • Intended use: This is going to be my only car, so it needs to be fairly reliable. I don’t need much space, because if I move I’ll use a truck. Room for one carry-on suitcase and a knapsack or two besides would be fine.

  • Vehicles you've already considered: Basically just the Miata. I wouldn’t get an NC, but ND 2017 models are creeping down into my price range. I’ve sort of got my heart set on an ND MX-5, but I’m scoping out alternatives, preferably ones a little cheaper.

  • Is this your 1st vehicle: First one I’m shelling out for. Not the first I’ve owned.

  • Do you need a Warranty: Need, no. Want, sure.

  • Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: I’m looking to learn, so this is not a deal-killer, but it can’t be engineered with a steep learning curve designed to irritate shadetree mechanics. I may also just not have a space to work on it.

  • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No.

  • Additional Notes: I’m going to have a hard time justifying a car more than 10 years old. I won’t be in a position to buy the car for at least a year, so cars just outside of my price range are fine on the assumption they’ll get cheaper. And like I said, I’m pretty set on a Miata, but looking for other small, fun options.

comment_body.65:
Fellas I'm very torn right now. I'm sick of only having an automatic transmission and want to change that. Money is a finite resource, but I want all the cars.

In an ideal world, I'd have a two-car garage with a Cadillac CT6-V and Corvette ZR1. A fast luxobarge for a daily, and extreme performance for the weekend. But I don't have a $200,000 budget. I have more like a $25,000 budget.

For sale locally there are a couple cars that interest me:

  • 73k B8.5 6MT Audi S4 for $25k

  • 56k C6 Z06 for $31k

  • 75k C5 Z06 for $17k

Here's my thoughts on the three:

The S4 - The most practical car to have as my only car. I can sell my G8 to help fund it. Would be an amazing daily driver for winters in Minnesota, and is plenty fun for ordinary highway driving. It's not impressively big, but I don't have rear passengers often. Driving a manual everywhere might get tedious. And lastly the cornering ability isn't incredible, but it probably still has plenty of fun even if the cornering ability isn't incredible. I could always save up and buy a weekend car, but then there's some redundancy having two manual transmission cars.

C6 Z06 - Stupid fast. Also pretty expensive. Idk if the extra $ over a C5 Z06 is worth it.

C5 Z06 - Plenty fast. Could always throw a supercharger or camshaft in it to make it even faster. Car is basically at the bottom of its depreciation curve. Cheap enough to thrash at autocross or track days without feeling bad about it. The low price point means I could save up for a luxobarge to replace my G8... or hell maybe even a pickup truck.

One of the things that I'm really torn on is I don't know if I'd really enjoy having a big luxury vehicle as much as I think I will. The Audi A8 4.0T and Cadillac CT6 3.0TT are pretty heavily depreciated and seem to offer a ton of value as daily drivers. But do they really offer much to me over a car like my G8 or an S4?

I think I need to evaluate what I really want in a car. I'm just coming here for second opinions.

comment_body.69:
A minivan is the best way to comfortably move around lots of people and stuff. And the Pacifica has been my favorite minivan in recent years. The plug-in hybrid is a pretty unique vehicle, with a usable electric-only range for shuttling family members around town, though you do miss out on Stow n Go seats, which are only available with gas-only models. In the US, you get federal tax credits for buying a plug-in hybrid like the Pacifica PHEV, and I'm assuming Canada has something similar. I will say, some folks have had minor issues and glitches with the Pacifica plug-in, so look around online for what problems folks have run into before deciding whether it's for you or not. It's just about the only plug-in people mover that meets your needs, for now!

If you end up checking out SUVs, the Kia Telluride and Hyundai Palisade are my favorites on the market, but the newly redesigned Toyota Highlander is an improvement on the previous model and comes with a great hybrid option.
